info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 6:59AM EST by NWS Blacksburg
info.description: ...Light Snow Accumulations Expected Through the Morning Hours... A band of light snow extending from northwest North Carolina into southwest Virginia and west central Virginia was continuing to drift slowly east. Snow accumulations of around an inch are common within this band of precipitation with a few spots across eastern West Virginia seeing amounts closer to 2 inches this morning. Temperatures have fallen below freezing in areas where the snow has been falling with most areas in the upper 20s to lower 30s. Untreated roads and sidewalks will become slick and hazardous. Although these snow accumulations fall short of typical Winter Weather Advisory levels, travel across this region this morning is discouraged. If you must travel through the morning hours today, reduce speed and drive slower than normal, allow extra time to reach your destination, leave extra distance between you and the vehicle in front of you. Avoid sudden breaking and accelerating and use extreme caution while traveling in more mountainous terrain. Note, a Winter Weather Advisory remains in effect for area further east and north from Blacksburg to Roanoke and north of Lynchburg. The heaviest snowfall is expected to occur in the Southern Shenandoah Valley from Lexington northward near the Interstate 81 corridor. If conditions become worse than expected at this time, a Winter Weather Advisory may be needed for other parts of the forecast area. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or visit our web site at www.weather.gov/blacksburg for further weather information.
